Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Application of Cluster Expansion Method to First-Principles Mineralogy
Award.AbstractNarration:
Since 2004, it has become clear that there is a transition between two different crystal structures affecting the major mineral present deep in the Earth?s mantle, or, within about 200 km of the boundary with the Earth's core. Experimental studies of this perovskite to post-perovskite transition are challenging, fragmentary and, when iron is included, mutually contradictory. This EaGER award will enable a preliminary computational study to complement some ongoing experimental efforts. Methods necessary to understand minerals with many possible atomic arrangements, widespread in modern materials science but little known in mineral physics, will be employed.

The importance of proper treatment of atomic arrangements in solid solutions, both for obtaining the configurational entropy and in its effect on the vibrational terms, seems to be little understood in the mineralogical community; many studies in computational mineral physics will benefit from raising the level of awareness of solid solutions and the availability of tools to address them. This work is intended to demonstrate their suitability for detailed follow-up studies of lower mantle mineralogy and also to spark a revolution in extension of first-principles methods beyond one-component systems, while training a graduate student with broad abilities in computational thermodynamics, experimental mineral physics, observational astronomy, and theoretical geophysical fluid dynamics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Earth's deep interior is inaccessible to direct observation, but its properties affect us here on the surface of the planet in many ways. Hence we need experimental and theoretical studies of the minerals that we believe to constitute the various layers of the Earth, in order to build a reasonably complete physical and chemical understanding of the processes going on at depth and in order to correctly interpret geophysical observations that indirectly probe the deep Earth. Experiments suggest that the dominant mineral of the lower mantle (670 to 2900 km depth, and hence most of the Earth by volume) is magnesium silicate perovskite containing a certain amount of iron and a variety of minor elements. The behavior of iron in this mineral has recently attracted great interest from mineral physicists. Experiments show that the behavior of the electrons bound to iron atoms in this structure -- the same electrons that give iron its magnetic character at ordinary conditions -- changes at high pressure, but in ways we don't yet understand because the experiments are difficult, expensive, sparse, incomplete and, in some cases, contradictory. This provides an opportunity for theoretical calculations to bring insight both to the interpretation of the experiments and the range of possibilities in nature.

We carried out a theoretical study of the behavior of iron atoms in the perovskite structure as a systematic function of iron/magnesium ratio (from pure magnesium all the way to pure iron end members of the system), pressure (from 0 to beyond the pressure of the Earth's core-mantle boundary), and spin state ("spin" is a property of electrons; it is really a quantum mechanical phenomenon but in practice electrons act like spinning tops that are either spinning clockwise -- spin up -- or counter-clockwise -- spin down). We used the methods of classical thermodynamics to systematize all our quantum-mechanical calculations and to generate predictions of the stability of different compositions and spin states under the conditions of Earth's lower mantle. This system-wide approach provides a much clearer view than can be obtained from experiments or computations applied to single compositions. The results offer key guidelines to near-future follow-up experiments that may confirm the predictions of the theory and, in turn, enable new and more accurate interpretation of seismological data in terms of composition and temperature. Finally, better knowledge both of the current state of the deep Earth and of the range of physically-accessible possible states of the deep Earth will enable better understanding of the evolution of the Earth as a system over time and of its deep past and its possible futures.

This work contributed to the training of a graduate student with a broad, multidisciplinary skill set of observational, experimental, theoretical, and computational tools. He promises to be a leader in the upcoming generation of scientists that will take astronomical observations of many, many new planets around other stars and turn them into concrete knowledge of the rich variety of origins and evolutionary pathways of Earth-like planets.
